messageBody:
IMHO, constructors ought to just construct an object to a sane state, anything
else should be external to the constructor. So, initially I would take a lot
of the 'functionality' and computation out of the constructor if possible.
Once the object is constructed, you should be able to test its state. If not,
there's a code smell there. So, I would suggest that you take what you can out
of the ctor, construct the object to its known/sane state, then test against
that.

HTH.
-jason
